resources.string: Unified English Braille - Modern standard for all English speaking countries
The letters - most braille texts just use these!
Beware: not all braille symbols are made up of a single cell! Some punctuation symbols need 2!
Cells following a Number Sign are read as numbers! The letters \'a\' - \'i\' correspond to \'1\' - \'9\', and \'j\' is \'0\'.
Wordsigns represent common words, and are often represented by the cell of their first letter(s)! They can usually only be used when standing alone (surrounded by spaces on both sides).
Groupsigns represent common letter groups! They can usually be used wherever the group appears, but there are some exceptions! Tap on any entry for more information.
These contractions are made up of 2 cells, with the second cell usually representing the first letter(s)! Some of these have strange usage rules, so beware! Tap on any entry for more information.
These contractions are made up of 2 cells, with the second cell usually representing the last letter(s)! They can generally be used anywhere except at the start of a word.
Shortforms allow you to abbreviate common words by missing out some letters! They can generally only be used when standing alone.
Standard for Swedish texts is to use full write. If there is information about a text (meta-data) then it usually says if full write or short write is used.
These symbols represent common words, but in more than 1 cell!
These represent common sounds within words!
These represent abbreviations of common phrases!
These symbols are used to represent letters used in other languages!
The 12 vowels of Tamil, along with the special character Ayutha Ezhuthu
The first set of compound letters, formed by the combination of Uyir Ezhuthukal (vowels) and Mei Ezhuthukal (consonants)
The remaining set of compound letters, formed by the combination of Uyir Ezhuthukal (vowels) and Mei Ezhuthukal (consonants)

The Number Sign sets 'Numeric Mode' for the remainder of the sentence.

This means that all Braille characters after the Number Sign should be read as numbers until Numeric Mode ends.

Numeric Mode is ended by spaces, the Letter Sign or any other character not shown in the numbers dictionary.

Some Braille characters can have more than one meaning; an uncontracted meaning and a contracted or numerical meaning.

In cases where this may be confusing for the reader, the 'Uncontracted Indicator' (Letter Sign) is placed before the character to set 'Uncontracted Mode'.

This tells the reader that the next symbol is not a contraction or a numeric value; it should be read as a letter or punctuation.

The next letter to come after a 'Capitalisation Indicator' (Capital Sign) is a capital letter.

The use of the Capital Sign sets 'Capitals Mode', which ends after the first letter.

For contractions, only the first letter in the contraction is capitalised.
The Capitals Word Indicator sets \'Capitals Mode\' for a whole word, after which it ends.\n\nThis means that the entire following word is capitalised.
\' can be used wherever the characters occur
\' can only be used when standing alone
\' cannot be used at the start of a word
\' can only be used when it forms the first syllable of a word
\' can only be used when surrounded by other letters
\' can only be used when the meaning of the original word is retained
\' can only be used when the \'a\' is short
\' can only be used when the stress is on the first \'e\', and it does not follow the letters \'i\' or \'e\'
\' can only be used when the letters it represents are pronounced as one syllable
\' can only be used when the letters it represents are pronounced as one syllable, or are used to end a word with the letters \'oney\'. It cannot ever be used after the letter \'o\'
\' can only be used when the letters it represents are pronounced in the same way as in the original word
\' can only be used when the letters it represents do not follow the letters \'a\' or \'o\', and the letters \'un\' do not form a prefix
\' can be used when or when surrounded either at the start, or at the end, or at both, with non-short-write symbols
\' can be used when preceded by non-short-write symbols
\' can be used when preceded by non-short-write symbols, or when standing alone
